editionStmt.edition: This early release includes some 500 EEBO-TCP transcriptions of Early Modern plays that have undergone several routines to create an interoperable and algorithmically amenable corpus of Early Modern Drama. Many incompletely or incorrectly transcribed words have been corrected, including obvious printers' errors, but the text has not been proofread word by word. Each word in the text has been identified as a distinct token with its own xml:id and assigned to a lemma, a part of speech, and a standard spelling. Speech prefixes were mapped to unique speaker ID's as "who" attributes of sp elements. elements

div.p: A right pithy, pleasant and merry comedy: entituled gammer Gurton's needle: played on stage, not long ago in Christ's college in Cambridge.
Made by Mr●. S. Mr. of art.
Imprinted at London in Fleetstreet beneath the conduit at the sign of s. John evangelist by Thomas Colwell.

div.head: ¶ The names of the speakers in this comedy.
¶ The prologue.
div.l: As gammer Gurton, with many a wide stitch
Sat pesynge and patching of Hodgher man's briche
By chance or misfortune as she's her grare to●●
In Hodge leather breeches her needle she lost ▪
When Diccon the bedlam had hard by report
That good gammer Gurton was ●ob●e in this sort,
He quietly persuaded with her in that stound
Dame chat her dear gossyp this needle had found,
Yet knew she no more of this matter (Alas)
Then knoweth Tom our clerk what the priest saith at mass
Here of there ensued so fearful a fray,
Mass doctor was sent for these gossyps to stay,
Because he was curate, and esteemed full wise
Who found that he sought not, by Diccon's device,
When all things were tumbled and clean out of fashion
Whether it were by fortune, or some other constellation
Suddenly the needle Hodge found by the pricking
And drew it out of his buttock where he felt it sticking
Their hearts then at rest with perfect security,
With a pot of good ale they stroke up their plaudite.

sp.speaker: Diccon
sp.l: Many a mile have I walked, divers and sundry wai●●
And many a good man's house have I been at in my days
Many a gossip's cup in my time have I tasted
And many a broche and spit, have I both turned and basted
Many a piece of bacon have I had out of their balks
In running over the country, with long and were walks,
Yet came my foot never, within those door ch●ekes,
To seek flesh or fish ▪ garlic, onions or leeks.
That ever I saw a sort, in such a plight
As here within this house ap●er●th to my s●ght,
There is howling and scowling a●l 〈…〉 adamye,
with whewling and puling, as though they had lost a trump
Sighing and sobbing, they weep and they wail
I marvel in my mind, what the devil they ail
The old trot sits groaning, with alas and alas,
And Tib wrings her hands, and takes on in worse case
With poor cock their boy, they be driven in such fits
I fear me the folks be not well in their wits,
Ask them what they ail, or who brought them in this stay?
They answer not at all, but alack and wellaway
When I saw it booted not, out at doors I hied me
And caught a slip of bacon, when I saw that none spied me,
Which I intend not far hence, unless my purpose fail
Shall serve for a shoeing-horn to draw on two pots of ale.

sp.speaker: Hodge
sp.l: See so cham arrayed with dabbling in the dirt
She that set me to ditching, ich would she had the squirt
Was never poor soul that such a life had?
Gog's bones this filthy glaye hase dressed me to bad
God's soul, see how this stuff tears
Iche were better to be a bearward and set to keep bears
By the mass here is a gash, a shameful hole in dead
And one stitch tear further, a man may thrust in his head.

sp.speaker: Diccon
sp.l: ¶ By my father's soul Hodge, if I should now be sworn
I can not choose but say thy breech is foul be torn,
But the next remedy in such a case and hap
Is to planch on a piece, as broad as thy cap.

sp.speaker: Hodge
sp.l: ¶ Gog's soul man, 'tis not yet two days fully ended
Since my dame Gurton (●hem sure) these breeches amended,
But Cham made suce a drudge to trudge at every need
Chwold rend it though it were stitched what sturdy packthread,

sp.speaker: Diccon
sp.l: ¶ Hoge, let thy breeches go, and speak and tell me soon
What devil aileth gammer gurton, and Tib her maid to frown,

sp.speaker: Hodge
sp.l: ¶ Tush man thou'rt deceived, ●ys their daily look,
They coure so over thecoals, their eyes be bleared with smoke,

sp.speaker: Diccon
sp.l: ¶ Nay by the mass, I perfectly perceived as I came hither
that either Tib and her dame hath been by the cares to gether
Or else as great a matter as thou shalt shortly see.

sp.speaker: Hodge
sp.l: ¶ Now iche beseech our lord they never better agree.

sp.speaker: Diccon
sp.l: ¶ By gog's soul there they sit as still as stones in the streite
As though they had been taken with fairies or else with some ill sprite

sp.speaker: Hodge
sp.l: ¶ Gog's heart, I durst have laid my cap to a crown
Chwould learn of some prancome as soon as ich came to town.

sp.speaker: Diccon
sp.l: ¶ Why Hodge art thou inspired? or didst thou thereof here?

sp.speaker: Hodge
sp.l: ¶ Nay, but ich saw such a wonder as ich saw nat this ▪ vii. year
Tom Tankard's cow (Be gog's bones) she set me up her sail
And flinging about his half acre frisking with her tail,
As though there had been in her arse a swarm of bees,
And Chad not cried tphrowh hoore, shed leapt out of his lees.

sp.speaker: Diccon
sp.l: ¶ Why Hodge lies the cunning in Tom tankards cow's tail?

sp.speaker: Hodge
sp.l: ¶ Well Ich chave hard some say such tokens do not fail,
But cast thou not till in faith Diccon, why she frowns or where at
Hath no man stolen her ducks or hens, or gelded gyb her cat

sp.speaker: Diccon
sp.l: ¶ What devil can I tell man, I could not have one word
They gave no more heed to my talk than thou wouldst to a lord

sp.speaker: Hodge
sp.l: ¶ Iche can not still but muse, what marvellous thing it is
Chyll in and know myself what matters are amiss.

sp.speaker: Diccon.
sp.l: ¶ Then farewell hodge a while, since thou dost inward haste,
For I will into the good wife chats, to feel how the ale doth taste.

sp.speaker: Hodge
sp.l: Cham aghast by the mass, ich wot not what to do
Chad need bless me well before ich go them to
Perchance some felon spirit may haunt our house indeed,
And then chwere but at noddy to venture where cha no need

sp.speaker: Tib,
sp.l: ¶ Cham worse than mad by the mass to be at this stay
Cham chid, Cham blamed, and beat on all th'hours on the day,
Lamed and hunger starved, pricked up all in jags
Having no patch to hide my back, save a few rotten rags.

sp.speaker: Hodge
sp.l: ¶ I say Tib, if thou be Tib, as I trow sure thou be,
What devil make ado is this, between our dame and thee.

sp.speaker: Tyb.
sp.l: ¶ Gog's bread Hodge thou had a good turn thou wart not here this while.
It had been better for some of us to have been hence a mile
〈◊〉 gammer is so out of course, and frantic all at ones
That co●ke our boy●● I poor wench, have felt it on our bones.

sp.speaker: H●●ge
sp.l: ●; what is the matter, say on Tib whereat she taketh so on.

sp.speaker: Tyb.
sp.l: ¶ 〈◊〉 is undone she say (Alas,) her joy and life is gone
If 〈◊〉 here not of some comfort, she is say but dead
Shall never ●ome within her lips, one inch of meat ne bread.

sp.speaker: Hodge
sp.l: ¶ 〈◊〉 la●●e Cham not very glad, to see her in this dump
Cholde a noble ●er stole hath fallen, and she hath broke her rump

sp.speaker: Tyb.
sp.l: ● nay and t●at were the worst, we would not greatly care
For bursting of her huckle bone, or breaking of her chair,
But greater, greater, is her grief, as hodge we shall all feel.

sp.speaker: Hodge
sp.l: ¶ Gog's wounds Tib, my gammer has never lost her needle?

sp.speaker: Tyb.
sp.l: ¶ Her needle.

sp.speaker: Hodge
sp.l: ¶ Her needle?

sp.speaker: T●b,
sp.l: ¶ Her neele by him that made me, it is true Hodge I tell thee.

sp.speaker: Hodge
sp.l: ¶ Gog's sacrament, I would she had lost, tharte out of her belli●
The devil or else his dame, they ought her sure a shame
How a murrion came this chance, (Say Tib) unto our dame?

sp.speaker: Tyb
sp.l: ¶ My gammer sat her down on her pes, and had me reach thy breeches
And ●y and by, a vengeance in it or she had take two stitches
To clap a clout upon thine arse, by chance a side she ●eares
And gyb our ●at in the milk pan, she spied over head and ears
Ah hoar, out these, she cried aloud, and swapped the breeches down
Up went her staff, and out leapt gyb, at doors into the town
And since that time was never wight, cold set their eyes upon it
Gog's malison cha●e cock and I, b●d twenty times light on it.

sp.speaker: Hodge
sp.l: ¶ And is not them my breeches sewn up, to morrow that I should were

sp.speaker: Tyb
sp.l: ¶ No in faith ●odge thy breeches lie for 〈◊〉 this never the ●ere.

sp.speaker: Hodge
sp.l: ¶ Now a vengeance light on all the sort, that better should have kept it,
The cat● the house, and t●b our maid, thatbetter should have swept it
S● where we cometh crawling, come on in twenty devil's way
Ye have made a fair day's work, have you not● pray you say.

sp.speaker: ●āmer
sp.l: Alas h●ge, alas. I may well curse and ban
this day that ever I saw it, with gyb and the milk pan
For these and ill luck to gather, as knoweth Cocke my boy
Have stack away my dear needle, and robbed me of my io●e
My fair long straight needle that was mine only treasure
The first day of my sorrow is, and last end of my pleasure.

sp.speaker: Hodge
sp.l: ¶ Might ha' kept it when ye had it, but fools will be fools still.
Lose that is vast in your hands, ye need not but ye will.

sp.speaker: Gammer
sp.l: ¶ Go hie thee tib, and run thou hoore, to th'end here of the town
Didst carry out dust in thy lap seek where thou pour'st it down
And as thou sawest me roking, in the ashes where I mourned
So see in all the heap of dust, thou leave no straw unturned.

sp.speaker: Tyb
sp.l: ¶ That chal gammer swythe and tyte, and soon be here again,

sp.speaker: Gāmer
sp.l: ¶ Tib stoop and look down to theground to it, and take some pain.

sp.speaker: Hodge
sp.l: ¶ Here is a pretty matter, to see this gere how it goes
By gog's soul I thank you would loes your arse, and it were loose
Your needle lost, it is pity you should lack care and endless sorrow
Gog's death how shall my breeches be sewed, shall I go thus to morrow

sp.speaker: Gāmer
sp.l: ¶ Ah Hodge, Hodge, if that ich could find my needle by the reed
Chould sow thy breeches ich promise y●, with full good double thread
And set a patch on either knee, should last this months twain
Now god and good saint sith I pray, to send it home again.

sp.speaker: Hodge
sp.l: ¶ Whereto served your hands and eyes, but this your needle to keep
What devil had you else to do ye kept ich wot no sheep
Cham fain a broad to dyg and del●e ▪ in water ▪ mire and clay
Sossing and possing in the dirt, still from day to day
A hundred things that be abroad, Cham set to see them we'll
And ●oure of you sit ●●le at home, and can not k●●pe 〈◊〉.

sp.speaker: Gammer
sp.l: ¶ My neele alas ich lost it hodge, what 〈◊〉 Ich m● up h●●t ●
To save the milk set up for thee, which g●b our c●t hath wasted

sp.speaker: Hodge
sp.l: ¶ The devil ●e burst both gib, and 〈…〉 th' all the rest
Cham alwa●es sure of the worst end, whoever have the best
Where ha you ben flaging abroad, since you your ●eele l●●t

sp.speaker: Gāmer
sp.l: ¶ Within the house, and at the door, sittin● by this same post
Where I was looking a long hour, before these folks came here,
But wellaway, all was in vain, my neel● is never th● n●r●.

sp.speaker: Hodge
sp.l: ¶ Set me a candle let me seek and grope wherever it 〈◊〉
Gog's heart ye be so foolish (Ich think) you kn●w● it not when you ●● see

sp.speaker: Gāmer
sp.l: ¶ Come hither cock, what cock I say.

sp.speaker: Cocke.
sp.l: ¶ How gammer.

sp.speaker: Gammer
sp.l: ¶ ●oe hie thee soon, and grope behind the old brass pan,
Which thing when thou hast done
There shalt thou find an old shoe, where in if thou look well
Thou shalt find lying an inch of a white tallow candle,
Light it, and bring it right away.

sp.speaker: Cocke.
sp.l: ¶ That shall be done anon.

sp.speaker: Gammer
sp.l: ¶ Nay tarry Hodge till thou hast light, and then we'll seek each one.

sp.speaker: Hodge
sp.l: ¶ Come away ye whoreson boy, are ye asleep : ye must have a crier.

sp.speaker: Cocke.
sp.l: ¶ Ich cannot get the candle light here is almost no fire.

sp.speaker: Hodge
sp.l: ¶ Chil hold the a penny Chil make that come if thatich may catch thine ears
Art deaf thou whoreson boy● cock I say, why canst not hears.

sp.speaker: Gammer
sp.l: ¶ Beat him not Hodge but help the boy and come you two together.

sp.speaker: Gammer
sp.l: How now Tib, quick let's here, what news thou hast brought hither.

sp.speaker: Tyb.
sp.l: ¶ Chave tossed and tumbled yender heap our and over again
And winnowed it through my fingers, as men would winow grain
Not so much as a hen's turd but in pieces I tore it
Or whatsoever clod or clay I found, I did not spare it
Looking within and eke without, to find your needle (Alas)
But all in vain and without help, your needle is where it was.

sp.speaker: Gammer
sp.l: ¶ Alas my needle we shall never meet, adieu, adieu for aye.

sp.speaker: Tyb.
sp.l: ¶ Not so gammer, we might it find if we knew where it say.

sp.speaker: Cocke.
sp.l: ¶ Gog's cross gammer if ye will laugh look in but at the door
And see how Hodge lieth tumbling and tossing amids the floury
Raking there some fair to find among the ashes dead
Where there is not one spark, so big as a pin's head,
At last in a dark corner two sparks he thought he sees
Which where indeed naught else but Gyb our cats two eyes
Puff quoth Hodge thinking thereby to have fire without doubt
With that Gyb shut her two eyes, and so the fire was out
And by and by them opened, even as they were before,
With that the sparks appeared even as they had done of yore,
And even as hodge blew the fire as he did think
Gyb as she felt the blast straight way began to wink,
till Hodge fell of swearing, as cam● h●st to his turn,
The ●●er was sure bewitched, and therefore would not burn:
At last Gyb up the slayers, among the old posts and pins,
And Hodge he hied him after till broke were both his shins:
Cursing and swearing oaths, were never of his making,
That Gyb would fire the house, if that she were not taken.

sp.speaker: Gammer
sp.l: ¶ See here is all the thought that the foolish Urchy● taketh,
And Lyb methink at his elbow almost as merry maketh
This is all the wit ye have when others make their mo●e,
Come down Hodge, where art thou and let the cat alone.

sp.speaker: Hodge
sp.l: ¶ Gog's heart, help and come up, Gyb in her tail hath fire.
And is like to burn all if she's get a little hire:
Come down (Quoth you,) nay then you might count me a patch,
The soul cometh down on your ●eads if it take once that thatch.

sp.speaker: Gammer
sp.l: ¶ It is the cat's eyes fool that shineth in the dark.

sp.speaker: Hodge
sp.l: ¶ Hath the cat do you think in every eye a spark.
¶ ●e, but they shine as like fire as ever man see.

sp.speaker: Hodge
sp.l: ¶ By the mass and she burn all, youth hear the blame for me

sp.speaker: Gāmer
sp.l: ¶ Come down and help to seek here our needle that it were found
D●wne ●yb on t●o knees I say, down C●ck● to the ground.
To God I make a vow, and so to good saint Anne
'A candle shall they have a piece, get it where I can,
It I may my needle find in one place or in other.

sp.speaker: Hodge
sp.l: ¶ Now a vengeance on 〈◊〉 light, on gyb and gybs mother
And all the generation of cats both far and near
Look on the ground ●orson thinks thou the needle is here.

sp.speaker: Cocke.
sp.l: ¶ ●y my troth gammer methought your needle here I saw
But when my fingers touched it, I ●ell it was a straw.

sp.speaker: Tyb
sp.l: ¶ See Hodge what's ty●, may it not be within it,

sp.speaker: Hodge
sp.l: ¶ Break it ●oo●e with thy hand and see and thou canst find it.

sp.speaker: ●yb
sp.l: ¶ Nay break it you Hodge according to your word.

sp.speaker: Hodge
sp.l: ¶ ●ogs ●ydes, fie it stinks ▪ it is a cat's turd,
It were well done to make thee ere it by the mass.

sp.speaker: Gammer
sp.l: ¶ This matter amendeth not my needle is 〈◊〉 where it was
Our candle is at an end let us all in ●u●ght
And come another time, wh●● we have more light

lg.l: ¶ Back and side go bare, go bare,
Booth foot and hand go cold:
But belly god send thee good ale enough,
Whether it be new or old.
I can not eat, but little meat,
My stomach is not good:
But sure I think, that I can drink
With him that wears a hood.
Though I go bare, take ye no care,
I am nothing a cold:
I stuff my skill, so full within,
Of jolly good ale and old.
Back and side go bare, go bare,
Booth foot and hand go cold:
But belly god send the good ale enough
Whether it be new or old.
I love no roast, but a nut brown toast
And a crab laid in the fire,
A little bread, shall do me stead
Much bread I not desire:
No frost nor snow, no wind I trow
Can hurt me if I would,
I am so wrapped, and throughly leapt
Of jolly good ale and old.
Back and side go bare. Etc.
And Tib my wife, that as her life
Loveth well good ale to seek,
Full oft drinks she, till ye may see
The tears run down her cheeks:
Then doth she troll, to me the bowl
Even as a malt worm should,
And say sweet heart, I took my part
Of this jolly good ale and old.
Back and side go bare. Etc.
Now let them drink, till they nod and wink,
Even as good fellows should do
They shall not miss, to have the bliss,
Good ale doth bring men to:
And all poor souls that have scoured bouls
Or have them lustily trolled,
God save the lives, of them and their wives
Whether they be young or old.
●acke and side go bare. Etc.

sp.speaker: Diccon
sp.l: Well done be gog's malt, well song and well said,
Come on mother chat as thou art true maid,
〈◊〉 fresh pot of ale let's see to make an end
Against this cold weather my naked arms to defend,
This gere it warms the so●le, now wind blow on the worst,
And let us drink and swill, till that our bellies burst
Now were he a wise man, by cunning cold define
Which way my journey lieth or where Dyccon will dine
But one good turn I have ▪ be it by night or day
South, East, North or West, I am never out of my way.

sp.speaker: Hodge
sp.l: ¶ Chym goodly rewarded, cham I not, do you think?
Chad a goodly dinner for all my sweat and swink,
Neither butter cheese, milk onions flesh nor fish
Save this poor piece of barley bread, 'tis a pleasant costly dish.

sp.speaker: Diccon
sp.l: ¶ Hail fellow Hodge and will to face, with thy meat, if thou have any!
But by thy words as I them smelled, thy daintrels be not many.

sp.speaker: Hodge
sp.l: ¶ Daintrels diccon (Gog's soul man (Save this piece of dry horsebread,
Cha bit no bit this live long day, no crome come in my head
My guts they yawl crawl and all my belly rumbleth
The puddings can not lie still, each one over other tumbleth
By gog's heart Cham so ver●e, and in my belly penned
Chould one piece were at the spittlehouse another at the castle's end.

sp.speaker: Diccon
sp.l: ¶ Why hodge, was there none at home thy dinner for to set:

sp.speaker: Hodge
sp.l: ¶ Godg● bread Diccon ich came too late, was nothing there to get
G●b (A ●owle fiend might on her light (Licked the milk pan so clean
See Diccon, 'twas not so well washed this vii year as ich were
A pestilence light on all ill luck, Chad thought yet for all this
of a morsel of bacon behind the do●● at worst should not miss,
But when ich sought a slip to cut, as ich was wont to do
Gog's soul Diccon, gyb our cat had 〈◊〉 the bacon to.
Which bacon Diccon stole, as is declared before.

sp.speaker: Diccon
sp.l: ¶ Ill luck quod he, marry swear it Hodge, this day thetruth to tell
Thou rose not on thy right side, or else bl●●t thee not well.
Thy milk slopped up, thy bacon filched, that was to bad luck Hodge.

sp.speaker: Hodge
sp.l: ¶ Nay, nay, there was a fouler fa●●t, my gammer game thedog
Seest not how cham rent and torn, my heels, my knees and my breech
Chad thought as ich sat by the fire, help here and there a stitch,
But there ich was powpte indeed.

sp.speaker: Diccon
sp.l: ¶ Why Hodge?

sp.speaker: Hodge
sp.l: ¶ Boots not man to tell,
Cham so dressed amongst a sort of fools, Chad better be in hell,
My gammer (Cham ashamed to say) by god served me not we'll

sp.speaker: Diccon
sp.l: ¶ How so Hodge?

sp.speaker: Hodge
sp.l: ¶ Hase she not gone trowest now and lost her needle.

sp.speaker: Diccon
sp.l: ¶ Her eel Hodge, who fished of late? that was a dainty dish.

sp.speaker: Hodge
sp.l: ¶ Tush tush, her needle, her needle, her neele man.
('tis neither flesh nor fish.
A little thing with an hole in the end, as bright as any syller,
Small, long, sharp at the point, and straight as any pillar.

sp.speaker: Diccon
sp.l: ¶ I know not what a devil thou meanest, thou bringst me more in doubt

sp.speaker: Hodge
sp.l: ¶ Knowest not with what Tom tailor's man, fits broaching through a clout
A needle, neele, a needle, my Gammer's needle is gone.

sp.speaker: Diccon
sp.l: ¶ Her neele Hodge, now I smell thee, that was a chance alone,
By the mass thou hadst a shameful loss, and it were but for that 〈◊〉

sp.speaker: Hodge
sp.l: ¶ Gog's soul man chould give a crown Chad it but iii. stitches.

sp.speaker: Diccon
sp.l: ¶ How sayest thou Hodge, what should he have, again thy n●●le got

sp.speaker: Hodge
sp.l: ¶ Gem vathers soul, and Chad it chould give him a new grot.

sp.speaker: Diccon
sp.l: ¶ Canst thou keep counsel in this case.

sp.speaker: Hodge
sp.l: ¶ Else chwold my thong were out.

sp.speaker: Diccon
sp.l: ¶ Do than but then by my advice, and I will fetch it without doubt,

sp.speaker: Hodge
sp.l: ¶ I'll run, I'll ride, I'll dig, chyl 〈◊〉,
(Chill toil, Chill trudge shalt see:
Chill hold Chil draw, Chil pull, Chill pinch
